scene.name: scene_0032
scene.title: [b]1.[/b] Pushkinskaya Street
scene.data:
Pushkinskaya Street

Pushkinskaya Street first appeared in the plan of the city of Rostov in 1870. Its original name is Kuznetskaya. In 1885, the city council decided to rename it, naming it after Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin.
Many of the more than two and a half thousand Rostov streets are named after writers. Only a few streets that existed before 1917 have preserved their original names after the classic writers - Pushkin, Lermontov, Tolstoy, Griboyedov and Derzhavin.

scene.name: scene_0001
scene.title: [b]2.[/b] Bronze Lions
scene.data:
Bronze Lions

We invite you in a tour along the most «literary» street of Rostov-on-Don. Along Pushkinskaya Street...
Our tour begins with four bronze lions located at four corners of the pedestrian alley of Pushkinskaya Street at the intersection with Semashko Lane. Their belonging to the street bearing the name of Pushkin is indicated by bronze figurines in the paws of lions - fairy-tale characters from the works of A.S. Pushkin, such as «Goldfish», «Swan Princess», «Frog Princess» and «Little Squirrel» from «The Tale of Tsar Saltan». The sculptor is David Rubenovich Begalov.

scene.name: scene_0004
scene.title: [b]4.[/b] House of Ivan Zvorykin
scene.data:
House of Ivan Zvorykin

The house of Ivan Zvorykin (House of Zaslavskaya) was built in 1914 by the architect Vasily Popov. In pre-revolutionary times, the house was occupied by the mayor of Rostov, Major General Ivan Nikolaevich Zvorykin, and the administration of Rostov-on-Don was located there. After the arrival of the Soviet power, the house was nationalized. There were various offices, residential apartments and a hostel of the school for training Soviet government and Communist Party workers. Some of the original decorative components has been lost.

scene.name: scene_0005
scene.title: [b]5.[/b] Kirshon’s House
scene.data:
Kirshon’s House

The three-storey building occupies the corner of the block, its front facades overlook Pushkinskaya Street and Semashko Lane. The house was built in the Art Nouveau style with Gothic elements. From 1923 to 1926, the Soviet playwright Vladimir Mikhailovich Kirshon lived in the house. Among other things, he is the author of the script for one of the first Soviet espionage-adventure films «Struggle for the Ultimatum». He is known to many people as the author of the poem «I’ve asked an ash tree» which sounds in the movie «The Irony of Fate or Enjoy Your Bath» set to the music of Mikael Tariverdiev.

scene.name: scene_0003
scene.title: [b]6.[/b] Alexander Fadeev
scene.data:
Alexander Fadeev

Vladimir Kirshon organized the Rostov and North Caucasian Association of Proletarian Writers. And in the fall of 1924, it was in this building that Alexander Fadeev read to Kirshon the manuscript of the novel «The Rout». It must be said that «The Rout» was mainly written by Fadeev in Rostov. The young writer lived and worked there from October 1924 to October 1926. The first excerpt from the novel first appeared in print in July 1925 in the «Sovetsky Yug» newspaper, where Fadeev was employed, and two more excerpts appeared in the «Lava» magazine of which he was one of the founders and editors. He left Rostov as a mature writer, author of a popular novel, «godfather» of many Don writers.

scene.name: scene_0006
scene.title: [b]7.[/b] memorial plaque of F.V. Tumilevich
scene.data:
Memorial plaque of F.V. Tumilevich

The second memorial plaque was installed in 1997 and was dedicated to the famous Don folklorist, scientist and writer Fyodor Viktorovich Tumilevich.
Fyodor Viktorovich and his wife Tamara Ivanovna have been collecting and researching the culture of the Nekrasov Cossacks for many years.

scene.name: scene_0007
scene.title: [b]8.[/b] Monument to A.S. Pushkin
scene.data:
Monument to A.S. Pushkin

At the intersection of Pushkinskaya Street and Voroshilovsky Avenue, there is a monument to Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin which was opened on 11 August 1959. The monument is an object of cultural heritage of regional significance and the first monument in Rostov-on-Don dedicated to literary themes...
Alexander Sergeevich Pushkin first visited Rostov-on-Don in 1820. Then, having gone to southern exile, he fell ill in Yekaterinoslav (now Dnepropetrovsk) and was allowed to go to the Caucasian Mineral Waters and to the Crimea for treatment, together with the family of General Raevsky who was heading there.

scene.name: scene_0008
scene.title: [b]9.[/b] Monument to A.S. Pushkin
scene.data:
Monument to A.S. Pushkin

The poet also passed the Don region in 1829, when without permission he went from St. Petersburg to the theatre of military operations in the Transcaucasus. During the journey, the poet’s interest in topics that later became the main ones in his work was formed, i.e. the military history of Russia, the reign of Catherine II and Peter, the history of the Cossacks, the characters of Stepan Razin and Emelyan Pugachev.
Rostov and the fortress located nearby gave the poet new, in many ways brighter and equally unforgettable impressions.

scene.name: scene_0009
scene.title: [b]10.[/b] Monument to A.S. Pushkin
scene.data:
Monument to A.S. Pushkin

Alexander Sergeevich’s trip to the Don region was rich in impressions. In 1829, the Don sparkling with its splendour inspired the poet to write the following lines:

Shining amid wide fields,
There it flows!.. Hello, the Don!
From your distant sons
I brought you a bow.

scene.name: scene_0010
scene.title: [b]11.[/b] Public Assembly
scene.data:
Public Assembly

The mansion was built by Pavel Ivanovich Kramer around 1914. He was a successful banker, but he took place in the history of the city as a collector of paintings. His collection of paintings is still kept in the Regional Art Museum.
The mansion adjoined the Kramer’s tenement house built a decade earlier.

scene.name: scene_0011
scene.title: [b]12.[/b] Public Assembly
scene.data:
Public Assembly

The two-storey mansion is located in the depths of the site and has a U-shape. The façade is designed in a neoclassical style. The centre of the façade is decorated with an arched bay window. On the sides, there are extended «wings» opposite each other.

scene.name: scene_0012
scene.title: [b]13.[/b] Public Assembly
scene.data:
Public Assembly

During the Civil War, Kramer left Rostov and the Kramer’s mansion was nationalized. Since the 1920s, it has been under the jurisdiction of the district health department. After the Great Patriotic War, the mansion housed a regional medical institution

scene.name: scene_0013
scene.title: [b]14.[/b] Public Assembly
scene.data:
Public Assembly

In 1982, after reconstruction, the building was transferred to the House of Writers and Composers. Now the building has been transferred to the Rostov Public Assembly.

scene.name: scene_0014
scene.title: [b]15.[/b] Monument to A.P. Chekhov
scene.data:
Monument to A.P. Chekhov

The monument to Anton Pavlovich Chekhov, a native of Taganrog, is located at the intersection of Pushkinskaya Street and Chekhov Street, it was installed in January 2010 to the 150th anniversary of the writer. For 26 years of creative work, Anton Pavlovich wrote about 900 different works, many of which have become the classics of the world literature.
The author of the monument is the Rostov sculptor Anatoly Sknarin.

scene.name: scene_0015
scene.title: [b]16.[/b] Monument to A.P. Chekhov
scene.data:
Monument to A.P. Chekhov

There are two places in the city associated with the writer. This is Maksimov’s house on Semashko Avenue, where there was once a shop in which the writer’s father, Pavel Yegorovich, served as a salesman. Chekhov’s father met his future wife, Yevgenia Yakovlevna Morozova, Chekhov’s mother, in Rostov-on-Don. There, in Rostov, his brothers were born. Chekhov stayed at the house of his school friend, at the intersection of Stanislavsky Street and Gazetny Lane. One of the first productions of «The Cherry Orchard» in Russia was staged at the Rostov Theatre.

scene.name: scene_0016
scene.title: [b]17.[/b] The SFedU Library
scene.data:
The SFedU Library

This building is one of the main architectural gems of Rostov-on-Don. Now it is the regional library of the Southern Federal University.
The mansion was built in 1914 according to the project of Leonid Fyodorovich Eberg (who later became the author of Landvorets and the Rostov Hotel). The mansion of Nikolai Paramonov, the son of the famous merchant Elpidifor Paramonov, who owned mills, steamers, grain warehouses, was built for his beloved and according to another version for his daughter.

scene.name: scene_0017
scene.title: [b]18.[/b] The SFedU Library
scene.data:
The SFedU Library

However, the mansion was used by its owners not for long – only for four years. In late February - early March 1918, the mansion houses the headquarters of the Rostov-Nakhichevan Revolutionary Committee, in fact, the headquarters of the Red Army in Rostov. A few months later, the headquarters of the White Army was located in the same building, where prominent leaders of the White Movement met such as Lavr Kornilov, Anton Denikin and Mikhail Alekseev, one of the main ideologists of the White Movement, i.e. personalities of historical proportions.

scene.name: scene_0018
scene.title: [b]19.[/b] The SFedU Library
scene.data:
The SFedU Library

At the end of 1918, a fire broke out in Paramonov’s house. In 1923 the building was restored. It housed a builders’ club and then a blood transfusion institute. In the 1930s, the mansion housed the Regional Museum of Local History.
During the Great Patriotic War, the building burned, however, the walls and colonnades were not significantly damaged. In 1947, it was decided to restore and transfer the building to the library of Rostov State University. The reconstruction with architectural replanning was supervised by Eberg. In 1957, the university was headed by Yuri Andreevich Zhdanov, under whose leadership the university was transformed from a provincial university into a leading educational institution in the country. In 2011, a bust to Yuri Andreevich Zhdanov was solemnly unveiled in front of the library building.

scene.name: scene_0019
scene.title: [b]20.[/b] Alley of Veteran Writers
scene.data:
Alley of Veteran Writers

In memory of the great compatriots, an alley of veteran writers appeared in the centre of Rostov-on-Don. The monument to the Don veteran writers was opened in Rostov-on-Don on the occasion of the 71st anniversary of the Great Victory. Three bronze busts: Mikhail Sholokhov, Vitaly Zakrutkin and Anatoly Kalinin were installed next to the Public Library on Pushkinskaya Street.

scene.name: scene_0020
scene.title: [b]21.[/b] Alley of Veteran Writers
scene.data:
Alley of Veteran Writers

Each of the writers went through the harsh roads of the Great Patriotic War and left a living memory of those years in his work. During the Great Patriotic War, Mikhail Sholokhov was a war correspondent of the Soviet Information Bureau, newspapers «Pravda» and «Krasnaya Zvezda», he gave his Stalin Prize for «Quietly Flows the Don» to the needs of the front. The war correspondent Sholokhov was at the forefront of all seven fronts and took part in the Battle of Stalingrad. Its events became the basis for the novel «They Fought for Their Motherland».

scene.name: scene_0021
scene.title: [b]22.[/b] Alley of Veteran Writers
scene.data:
Alley of Veteran Writers

The future author of the «Gypsy» Anatoly Kalinin marched from the Terek to the Danube as part of the Fifth Don Cossack Corps. He was also a war correspondent, wrote for «Komsomolskaya Pravda».

scene.name: scene_0022
scene.title: [b]23.[/b] Alley of Veteran Writers
scene.data:
Alley of Veteran Writers

Another war correspondent, Vitaly Zakrutkin published two books of battle essays and about 100 works of fiction about the heroes of the war during the war years. He took part in the battles for Rostov-on-Don, the liberation of Prague, the storming of Berlin. Vitaly Zakrutkin volunteered for the front as a war correspondent for the 56th Army newspaper «For Our Motherland». He took part in the battle for the Caucasus, in the battles for Rostov-on-Don, the liberation of Prague, the storming of Berlin. During the war, he published two books of battle essays, published over 100 works of fiction about the heroes of the war.

scene.name: scene_0023
scene.title: [b]24.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

The first public library in Rostov-on-Don opened on 7 January 1886. From 1921 to 1994, the library was located in Velikanova’s mansion on Serafimovich Street.

scene.name: scene_0024
scene.title: [b]25.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

In 1974, the construction of a new library building began on Pushkinskaya Street. It was designed by the architect Yan Zanis and the engineer Boris Sidelkovsky. On 25 May 1994, the library moved to a new location.

scene.name: scene_0025
scene.title: [b]26.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

The buildings of the library are located perpendicular to each other. The main sculptural accent of the 16-storey monolithic concrete building is the relief framing the upper corner of the book depository facade.

scene.name: scene_0026
scene.title: [b]27.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

Moscow monumental artists Vladimir Lemport and Nikolai Silis created a stylized set of images-signs, including images of the “faces of the geniuses of mankind” between the book pages.

scene.name: scene_0027
scene.title: [b]28.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

Three months after the opening, in September 1994, the library hosted a meeting of the writer Alexander Solzhenitsin with the readers and the public of the city. In 1995, the library was given the status of the Central Library of the Rostov Region.

scene.name: scene_0028
scene.title: [b]29.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

The reading rooms occupy the three-storey blocks built in the same architectural style.

scene.name: scene_0029
scene.title: [b]30.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

The deliberate restraint of the external appearance of the library buildings is combined with the diversity in the library’s interior. The walls are finished with white granite and marble.

scene.name: scene_0030
scene.title: [b]31.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

The halls are decorated with cascades of waterfalls and pools. All this is complemented by an abundance of greenery and various sculptural compositions.

scene.name: scene_0031
scene.title: [b]32.[/b] Don Public Library
scene.data:
Don Public Library

Cities are like people: each has its own appearance, its own biography. The architecture of the city of Rostov-on-Don can be read as a chronicle of the development of our state since the 18th century, or it can be read as a fascinating book, created with the participation of many writers and poets associated with the Don region, who glorified or visited it.
